segments.text: fell unconscious at my feet.
And the headlinesman came over and asked, what's wrong with him?
In my naivete about medical matters, I said, I don't know.
I think he's knocked down.
The official then made the first mistake.
By rolling.
This lifeless body over.
And we could see no color in his eyes.
He then signaled for some players to come from the sideline.
And carry himple.
Off the field of play, which they did without a stretcher.
He regained consciousness before the game was over.
but could not move his arms and legs.
Saturday morning, back in Orange, we learned that his spinal cord had been broken just below the base of his neck, and he died Monday.
An unforgettable lesson about important things in life and its meaning.
In track, I tried to be a sprinter and ran on the relay teams.
But again, we were not very outstanding.
When commencement came, I believe that I was third in the class.
Our valedictorian, Charles McCormick, set some academic achievement marks that probably still are unbroken.
His average was astonishingly high.
His great handicap was that he had no personality.
If you gave him the material to memorize, he could do so quickly and hand it back to you verbally or in writing.
But if you ask him to work with people, to understand an athletic event,
or be friendly.
He did not know how to do that.
The number two person in the class, Charles Anderson, didn't go to college because his family owned many hundreds of rice land under which there was some nice oily liquid.
For me, the choice was Austin College.
The reverend
Dr. Drake had encouraged me to consider it one day in a conversation at church.
Then at summer church camp, before my senior year in high school, there were a number of people who spoke highly of Austin College.
And we went, mother and dad took me there to visit the day after Christmas in 1947.
Being naive about such matters, it did not occur to us that colleges closed down a great deal, closed down during the Christmas break.
We entered what seemed to be a very large main building.
and soon encountered what I thought was an old guy in the hallway.
We asked if he could help us find the president's office and he invited us to follow him and he would lead us there.
We walked down the hallway, we walked to the left of the
and he walked behind the president's desk and introduced himself as Edward B.
Grant, G-U-E-R-R-A-N-T, who was, in fact, the president.
His cordial welcome attracted our confident
And so I headed in that direction.
A few months later in the summer of 1948.
While visiting grandparents.
I went to Sherman.
Introduce myself to the football coach.
Whose name I cannot remember at this moment.
who turned out to have been the captain of the last Newt Rockne, K-N-U-T-E, R-O-C-K-N-E, that last Newt Rockne team at Notre Dame.
I went up for early practice for the Austin College Kangaroos and was delighted to be on that campus.
From the first day until the present, it has seemed that for this student, Austin College was just right.
A comparatively small liberal arts college, which provided a lot of direct personal attention to each student.
and real development, their personality and talent.
I lived in what we called Kangaroo Manor, a World War II one-story barrack building which had been moved to the campus as a residence for members
Of the athletic squad of the AC athletic squad.
Good fortune came my way and having a history course.
From Henry M Sidner, SYDNOR.
member of an old Virginia Presbyterian family who was in his first year of service at Austin College, having served in the public school system of West Virginia for a number of years.
Mr. Sedner's manner made a lifetime shaping impact
And also I became a close friend of the older Sidner son, Ned.
Within the next two and a half years,
I got to visit the Sidner home, two blocks south of the campus, and was impressed that there were books on the shelves and art on the walls.
Mrs. Sidner seemed to be a remarkably talented cook, and I ate food that I had never seen before.
They went birdwatching, which at first seemed to me to be a waste of time.
But then that effort soon imparted a greater interest in and knowledge of wildlife.
My

Extracurricular activities during those years included work on the campus paper based on having worked, having been a member of the staff of the high school paper, the Tiger Scratches, and the Stark High Yearbook, the Orange Peel.
I was in the kangaroo band for a time.
Also, and enjoyed the opportunity to be included in many activities.
The realities of the world changed
the realities of the world became more instant early in 1950 when Ned Sidner and I sat behind his father
and Jemmy Story, S-T-O-R-E-Y, a member of the religion faculty and a dear friend of the Sidners.
At a baseball game where Chuck Taylor, representing the Converse Shoe Company,
One of the old one of the original Boston Celtics gave us an exhibition of basketball.
Soon after the game that event was over.
Mr Sidner had a heart attack and died in a few hours.
Within a few weeks, Mrs Sidner asked me if I would like to come and
rent a room at their house since she was in need of cash.
I did and that cemented more deeply my respect for that family and tied me more closely to the dream of becoming a college faculty member.

Far back in the trailer house days, I had concocted a dream of going to West Point, possibly because Glenn Davis and Doc Blanchard had led the Army football teams to some memorable winning streaks, to a memorable winning streak during the war.
I wrote to the Congressman
and told him of my dream to go to West Point using writing and pencil on notebook paper without my parents' knowledge.
He responded by telling me that I would need to get a little older and become prepared for the
for the great competition to go to the Military Academy.
Thus, I should take the college preparatory courses and send him my grades at the end of each semester.
With that encouragement, I quietly proceeded with that task.

applied for the appointment my senior in high school and was identified as an alternate appointee if the principal one of the principals turned down he since i was 17 since my 17th birthday occurred in the spring of my senior year he suggested that i go on to college
take a full college prep year, and then, if I did well, he would appoint me the following year.
As we proceeded with those realities, I was to go to Fort Sam Houston, take a final exam to ensure that I would be qualified for the West Point
And mention was made of my taking an oath.
Of eight years service.
When I raised the question that West Point was only a four year institution.
I received the shocking response that after West Point I would be required to serve four years of active duty.
Quickly, I knew that I did not want to do that.
And so that.

dream vanished instantly it must have been paragraph it must have been the influence of mr sidner and a few others that turned me toward the hope of being a college faculty member enjoying history and literature courses
Equally, I majored in history and English, taking a lot of American history and American literature courses.
Because the tuition at Austin College
The tuition fee required that everyone pay full tuition if they took 12 hours or more, but it allowed anyone who paid that fee to take as many hours as they wanted.
I took an overload almost every semester.
And as I entered my fourth year at the college, was nearing graduation.
Mr. Sidner had been replaced by another teacher who touched my life.
markedly, Elmer Flaccus.
Professor Flaccus was a notable, quote, character because of his idiosyncrasies, sense of humor, and occasional displays of disorganization.
On the other hand, he was a very sensitive, helpful, and generous person.
At one in one long conversation when I indicated to him my goal.
My dream of being a college faculty member.
But.
Being with.
Out.
Any real knowledge of what it might.
Take in time.
Ability and expenditures.
To get a PhD.

He suggested that I finish my undergraduate degree the first semester of my senior year and then stay at Austin College that spring and begin work on a master's degree, which required 24 course hours and six hours of credit for the thesis.
I took 18 hours that semester.
And he helped me try to locate employment in the Sherman area for the 1952-53 year, while I completed the other master's courses at night and Saturdays.
That opportunity came at Denison High School.
So for my fifth year out of high school, I lived in Luckett Hall, the AC Dramatory, the first semester, and then rented a room from the Story family the second semester.
An arrangement which allowed me to behave like a true professional in the daytime.
but to return to undergraduate events at night and on weekends.
My teaching load at the high school was four sophomore level classes in Western Civilization.
a ninth grade literature class, and a ninth grade homeroom.
The principal, a very highly regarded leader, Truman Smith, asked me what I was taking on Monday nights.

When I indicated I had not yet gotten my schedule, he suggested I schedule something on Monday nights because the Denison High School PTA met that evening and they expected every faculty member to be present, but that if I had a course that night, they would certainly forgive my absence.
In addition, he urged me not to be seen attending any movie in Denison on Sunday evening because many conservatives in that town believed that such attendance was a violation of the Sabbath.
He also added, quote,
These folks wouldn't care if you went to the picture show in Sherman because most Denison people believe that town is filled with sand anyway.
Period, paragraph.
Early in 1953, I came back from work at Denison High one afternoon.
and was chatting with a buddy who was president of the AC student body that year, Jim Wilson.
An English major, he also was dreaming of becoming a
college faculty member, so I asked him where he thought he was going to graduate school.
When he indicated that his choice was Rice, I tried to make him aware that Rice did not offer.
degrees in the humanities and social sciences since all it did was quote engineering, architecture, and the natural sciences.
He quickly grabbed a catalog, reaffirmed the availability of English, and then after turning a few more pages,
informed me that Rice even offered a PhD in history.
Paragraph.
Knowing that Rice was totally tuition free for all students, I quickly asked for the catalog and verified the accuracy of his statement about the availability of history.
In a few moments, I made my way to the Luckin Hall doorway of the Dean of Students, Rollin Montfort Rolf, R-O-L-F-E, M-O-N-T-F-O-R-D, R-O-L-L-I-N, Rollin Montfort Rolf.
Dean Rolf was to most of us a
Truly distinctive individual.
Cadaverously thin.
Devoid, as far as we were aware, of much personality.
We usually called him the skeleton.
I quickly asked him if he would be willing to write me and I asked if he had if it was true that he had gone to rice.
He responded affirmatively and added that he had been president of first.
Graduating class there in 1916.
Then I asked if he would write a letter of recommendation in my behalf.
A quiet smile was his response.
and a bit of head shake, and he indicated no.
Quote, no.
I don't think I should.
Let me just write a couple of notes to some old friends.
Assuming that he had remembered some of my mischief and pranks as an undergraduate,
I feared that I might not have much chance to get in.
But within a few days I received an affirmative acceptance.
And later that fall learned that the two quote friends that he had contacted
were named McCann, M-C-C-A-N-N, and McCance, M-C-C-A-N-T-S, his classmates, one of whom was the chairman of the Graduate Admissions Committee and the other the vice chairman.
The realities of the war had almost complicated, had complicated this routine a bit.
The Korean War began in the summer of 1950 at the end of my sophomore year.
As the fall semester began, it seemed that the American troops were winning that conflict
And there was even a promise that, quote, the boys will be home by Christmas.
When that season came, however, the Red Chinese had joined the attack on the Americans and the South Koreans, and everything seemed bleak.
Many college males did not even return after the Christmas holidays.
and I, being very draftable, soon joined the Naval Reserve there in Sherman.
In the spring of that year at Denison High School, I received a notice to report for the draft on May 15, 1953.
I sought the advice
of the Naval Reserve Chief Petty Officer.
And he informed me that, he made me aware of the fact that I would have an automatic one year delay in reporting for active duty because of my having joined the Naval Reserve
in January of 1951.
And I told him that I had been admitted to Rice and I sure would like to finish that next year with that delay.
He then suggested that I write to the draft board in Orange and ask for a one month delay in order to finish the year at Denison High School, the 1952-53 year at Denison High School.
If they granted that month delay, then I could finish, would have a year delay from that date.
Thankfully, the Orange Draft Board did so, and so I went on to Rice.
Luckily, Jim Wilson joined me, and we
rented a room at 410 Emerson from a delightful lady who was the grandmother of one of our coed friends at Austin College.
Her house in an older section of town was a very comfortable place.
And for $30 a month, we had a place to sleep and could put a few items in the refrigerator and cook on a hot plate.
The courses at Rice were truly demanding.
Quickly, I learned that Rice students were well prepared
But I survived the year and then went off to the Navy in Charleston.
That experience was truly unforgettable.
Now we're going to cease.
Now back after an interruption for gas.
